title: The impact of high sex ratios in urban and rural China
abstractText:
In China there are currently 120 male births for every 100 female. By 2020 there will be over 20 million more men than women of marriageable age.  These imbalances are already affecting the reproductive age group, yet lack of empirical studies means the consequences of this huge surplus of men remain unknown.

The aim of this study is to explore the demographic, social and psychological consequences of high sex ratios in China. It will be carried-out at twelve field sites in Zhejiang, Henan  and Yunnan provinces, representing east, central and western regions, and where sex ratios in 2005 were 115 and 130 and 109 respectively.  The study comprises three components: first, a comparison of key sociodemographic indicators across the twelve sites, followed by  interviews with young adults and opinion leaders to explore awareness and attitudes about high sex ratios, and finally a questionnaire survey among 7000 young adults, to assess psychological well-being, attitudes and behaviours towards sex and gender roles, and aggressive tendencies.

This study will be the most rigorous exploration of the impact of high sex ratios on men, women and society in the world literature.  It will inform policy about the management and prevention of high sex ratios.
